titlepage.titleproper:
Finding aid for
Elizabeth W. Bauer Papers, 1958-2013
titlepage.author:
Finding aid created by
Patricia Ryan, April 2014

did.abstract: Elizabeth W. Bauer is a disability rights activist who served many years defending the rights of the disabled within Michigan, across the country, and internationally. She also served an eight year term on Michigan's State Board of Education. This collection contains materials relating to different disability rights issues--such as deinstitutionalization, community placement, euthanasia, sterilization, and disability legislation--as well as papers regarding the many organizations through which Bauer enacted her work.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: This collection was donated by Elizabeth W. Bauer (donor number 10,999) in September 2013.

accruals.p: No further additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Elizabeth W. Bauer papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Elizabeth W. Bauer, born December 28, 1937, received her Bachelor of Arts in Religion with a Minor in Speech Pathology from Mount Holyoke College in South Hadley, Mass. Upon her graduation, Bauer conducted post graduate study in Speech Pathology at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis. Bauer then continued her education at The Ohio State University in Columbus, where she received her Master of Arts in Education for Exceptional Children. She completed her studies by conducting doctoral studies at Michigan State University in East Lansing, in Education Administration.

After moving to Michigan in 1975, Bauer began her career in public service as an Adult Special Education Services Administrator and Special Education Teaching Consultant within the School District of the City of Pontiac in Pontiac. During this time, Bauer was responsible for identifying and creating education placements for people with disabilities over the age of 18. Within this position, she helped more than 200 people complete educational programs (Adult Basic Education, GED, High School Diploma) and become gainfully employed.

Bauer then went on to serve as Director of training for the Michigan Department of Mental Health at its Plymouth Center for Human Development in Northville, Mich. In this position, she was responsible for directing 30 professional and paraprofessional educators to provide staff development programs for more than 1,000 facility personnel. At the time, the Plymouth Center for Human Development was under court order to upgrade its services. Bauer directed that staff receive 120 hours of pre-service and 80 hours of in-service training, and built a training program that became the model of public mental health facilities in Michigan.

Next, Bauer worked as an administrator within the Developmental Disabilities Community Residential Services Division of the Michigan Department of Mental Health. In this position, Bauer directed a staff to coordinate the task of four Michigan Mental Health agencies to develop community-based residential services for persons with developmental disabilities in Wayne, Oakland, and Macomb counties. This effort resulted in helping more than 1,000 persons with mental and developmental disabilities to leave institutional settings for real homes in the community, in addition to school programs and community jobs.

In 1981, Elizabeth Bauer founded and became the executive director of Michigan Protection and Advocacy Service (MPAS)--Michigan's federally mandated protection and advocacy system for people with disabilities. The organization was designated to implement protection and advocacy systems for people with developmental disabilities, mental illness, HIV/AIDS and other disabilities pursuant to federal and state laws. During her time as executive director, MPAS was able to help thousands of people with disabilities achieve their objectives of protection from abuse, neglect, and discrimination and trained thousands to advocate for themselves and others.

After retiring from MPAS in 2001, Bauer was elected in 2002 to the State Board of Education for an eight year term during which time she led the State Board's educational technology initiative and was a member of the National Association of State Boards of Education (NASBE) Work Group on Career and Technical Education. She received the NASBE Distinguished Service Award in 2012.

In addition to her work with MPAS and the Michigan School Board of Education, beginning in 1994, Bauer worked as a self-employed consultant, focusing on human rights, civil society, and organization development with particular attention to rights and opportunities for people with disabilities in the United States, as well as countries including Armenia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Georgia, Hungary, Kosovo, Mexico, Peru, Romania, Russia, Serbia, Turkey, Ukraine, and Vietnam. As of 2014, in addition to her continuing work as a consultant, Bauer serves as president of the Board of Directors for the Widening Advancements for Youth (WAY) Academy of Detroit, a Charter school for students in need in South West Detroit, Mich.

scopecontent.p: Collection contains materials relating to different disability rights issues, records regarding the many organizations through which Bauer enacted her work, papers relating to Bauer's term as an elected official on the State Board of Education, materials relating to the conferences and workshops Bauer held and attended, Bauer's speeches and writings, and a very small personal series.

The collection is divided into seven series: the Personal series, the Organizations series, the Social Issues series (divided into 7 subseries: Bio-ethics and Disability Rights, Building Feasibility Study, Community Living/Group Homes, Deinstitutionalization, Mental Disability and the Law, Patient Abuse, and Miscellaneous), the Education series, the Conferences and Workshops series, the International Consultation series, and the Speeches and Writings series.

scopecontent.p: The Personal series (0.1 linear feet, 1979-2011) contains a paper written by Elizabeth Bauer's daughter, Anna McTigue, family photographs, personal correspondence, and Bauer's submission to Who's Who in the Midwest in 1979.

did.unittitle: Who's Who in the Midwest submission

scopecontent.p: The Organizations series (3.5 linear feet, 1971-2012) includes material related to different organizations Elizabeth Bauer was associated with, whose primary concerns were disability issues, services, and policy. The series consists of meeting agenda and minutes, handwritten notes taken by Bauer, correspondences, memorandums, newsletters, newspaper clippings, reports, and program information regarding programs run by these organizations that Bauer was a part of.

scopecontent.p: The Social Issues series (7 linear feet, 1963-2013) contains material relating to different social issues particularly pertinent to disability rights. The series has been divided into seven subseries.

The Bio-ethics and Disability Rights subseries (1.3 linear feet, 1972-2013) details issues such as assisted suicide, euthanasia, genetics procedures, refusal of medical services, rationing care to the developmentally disabled, and sterilization of the developmentally disabled. The subseries contains information on high profile court cases regarding these issues, meeting minutes and notes from the Children's Hospital of Michigan Bio-ethics Committee, newspaper clippings, newsletters, research papers, and correspondence.

did.unittitle: Children's Hospital of Michigan Bio-ethics Committee
Children's Hospital of Michigan Bio-ethics Committee

Medical ethics Resource Network of Michigan

MPAS' death and dying procedure proposal
Sterilization of the developmentally disabled in Michigan

scopecontent.p: The Building Feasibility Study subseries (0.3 linear feet, 1990-1990) concerns a study conducted by the Michigan Department of Mental Health in order to analyze facility needs to support state mental health services. This subseries contains correspondence regarding the study, the executive summary and background information of the study, as well as the many reports conducted in relation to the study.

did.unittitle: Inventory Survey and evaluation of Existing Facilities
Prototype Psychiatric Hospital Generic Program Statement

scopecontent.p: The Community Living/Group Homes subseries (3.4 linear feet, 1975-2003) details issues involved with helping those who are developmentally disabled assimilate into community settings and the push-back from communities against group homes. This subseries includes litigation involving group home cases, research papers, newspaper clippings, notes taken by Bauer, correspondence, testimonies by Bauer regarding the issue, surveys and reports, and informational booklets and resource guides.

scopecontent.p: The Deinstitutionalization subseries (1 linear foot, 1973-2012) details the issue of the closure of state mental health institutions, particularly those associated with the state of Michigan. This subseries contains newspaper clippings, correspondence, reports, public hearings, and photographs, as well as information regarding the shut-downs of specific state institutions and the transfer of patients.

did.unittitle: MPAS Responses to Voice of the Retarded
Pennhurst Longitudinal Study: Combined Report of Five Years of Research and Analysis

scopecontent.p: The Mental Disability and the Law subseries (0.4 linear feet, 1969-2012) contains materials relating to the history of law relating to mental disability. Included in this subseries are reports, legislative correspondence, the Michigan Bar Journal, court cases, and disability laws.

did.unittitle: Winfield State Hospital and Training Center (Bauer consultation)
Reports to the Michigan state legislature

scopecontent.p: The Patient Abuse subseries (0.2 linear feet, 1978-2011) details the issue of patient abuse within state institutions and nursing homes in the state of Michigan. This subseries contains reports and newspaper clippings.

did.unittitle: Guidelines for Assessing Parenting Capabilities in Child Abuse and Neglect Cases
Joint Committee to Study Abuse in State Mental Health Facilities
Nursing Homes: Abuse and Neglect throughout Michigan
Staff Report on the Institutionalized Mentally Disabled

scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous subseries (0.4 linear feet, 1963-2013) contains materials regarding social issues in mental health and disability rights that do not fit into any of the other subseries. Topics covered in this subseries include disability policy in Michigan, the education of developmentally delayed individuals, mental health issues in Michigan, women and disability, sexuality and people with handicaps, and recreation programs for developmentally delayed persons. This subseries includes newspaper clippings, as well as papers and reports regarding various mental health topics.

odd.p: (EDC [Education Development Center] projectbook, February 27, 2003. Lists EDC project descriptions. Includes index; 122 pages.)

scopecontent.p: The Education series (1.8 linear feet and 70.1 MB, 1958-2013) gives an in-depth picture of education initiatives in Michigan throughout the years, as well as details Bauer's 8 year term serving on the Michigan State Board of Education. Some topics discussed within this series include alternative education, special education services in Michigan, the education of homeless or at-risk youth, inclusive education, Universal Design Learning (UDL), higher education, technology in Michigan schools, intelligent design, and international education. This series contains meeting minutes, reports, surveys, newspaper clippings, newsletters, correspondence, information packets, research papers, CDs, and assessment materials.

scopecontent.p: The Conferences and Workshops series (1.8 linear feet, 1971-2012) contains materials relating to the many conferences that Bauer attended over the years, as well as materials regarding workshops that she put on within her work. Topics covered at these conferences include public health, advocacy for developmentally delayed individuals, mental health, disability law, community support services, special education, human sexuality and developmentally delayed persons, and pediatric AIDS, among others. This series contains notes taken by Bauer at the conferences, informational packets about conferences and workshops, and materials covered in conference proceedings.

scopecontent.p: The International Consultation series (0.5 linear feet, 1986-2004) details the work that Bauer did as a disability and human rights consultant in the Czech Republic, Hungary, and Kosovo. This series contains reports, correspondence, meeting proceedings, training materials, informational packets, and photographs. Some materials within this series are in languages other than English.

The Speeches and Writings series (1.7 linear feet and 8.2 MB, 1973-2010) contains the speeches that Elizabeth Bauer gave over the course of her career as a disability rights advocate and as a member of the Michigan State Board of Education, in addition to the writings and publications that she has produced over the years. Topics discussed within this series include: parenting children with epilepsy, bringing about change at the facility and community level, parent-professional relationships, advocacy challenges, disability rights, communities in schools, achieving independence with disability, special education, and the role of the government in the delivery of mental health services, among others.
